So I wanna dive deeper on this with you

For all the details or a refresher,
I'll link to that video down below.

We had an Abercrombie ad that

with many people just focusing
on the largest person.

And a lot of people saw
that as promoting obesity.
Whereas I and others just saw this
as someone being included,

even noting that over 42%
of Americans are obese.

So this was essentially a
clothing company going like,
"Hey, our clothes will fit you 42%."

And something I always try

is I've been every size,
whether I'm big, I'm small,
I'm whatever, and same for you.
You have value.

You can love yourself while
at the same time going,

"Hey, I should probably make
some healthier decisions,"
and your size shouldn't dictate
whether it's okay or not to bully you.
It's not okay.

It's also, as we talked
about, not fucking helpful.
But also with that,

I think it's important
that we don't shy away

from the very real health
problem we have in this country.

And for example, you
recently had NPR reporting,

"Diet-related deaths
outranked deaths from smoking,

and about half of US
deaths from heart disease,

nearly 900 deaths a day,
are linked to poor diet,"

and noting, "The pandemic
highlighted the problem,

with much worse outcomes
for people with obesity
and other diet-related diseases,"

especially as we continue
to see studies finding
that ultra-processed foods are linked
to cancer and early death,

things like prepackaged
soups, sauces, frozen pizza,

ready-to-eat meals, hot
dogs, sausages, French fries,

sodas, store-bought cookies,
cakes, candies, donuts,

With a number of people

are also some of the most affordable.
Because in this country,
we also have a food insecurity problem.
And as NPR notes there,

"The US can't fix hunger by
just feeding people cheap,
high-calorie, processed foods,

which is the food that's so
abundant in our food supply,"
which is why we're seeing a new report,
putting out recommendations.
The first being treat food as medicine,
noting that there's mounting evidence
that providing prescriptions

for fruit and vegetables can

with there also being an

Two, focus on quality of

processed foods like chips
and soda can set you back less

We've actually seen

if you get food stamps,

There've also been things

which doubles the value

But those are small programs

at a nationwide scale.
And among the other seven,
which I'll link to down below,
one of them is having a federal food czar,
with the recommendation noting,

"The US government spends more

and the healthcare system also
spends billions of dollars

with the taskforce pointing

and agencies without
harmonization or synergy.

The idea being that if

there's not this grand plan

there's just gonna be a lot of waste.
And we got to say, "Hey, we tried.
We threw money at the problem

meaningful change."
I mean, it's gonna be interesting to see
what changes do we potentially see

with the country continuing
to get more and more obese.

And also how effective

Because yes, there are

And so I do think trying

And I guess why this has been
in my head, as I wanna say,
I think there are two separate issues.

I do genuinely think that
we have a health crisis
in this country.
But that does not make villainizing

And showcasing that larger

And in that space,

one of the only areas

that they should maybe

And of the calories they were getting in,

Well, everyone can have

As far as everyone,
as far as that being a general statement,
that's not fatphobic, that's science.
It's literally part of a doctor's job.

You can't compare your general

When I was at my biggest,

The future of this country is at stake
in these upcoming midterms

and unfortunately, in
pretty much every election
for the very near future.

While understandably
going into these midterms,

many people are just focused
on the House and the Senate,
there's much more at play here.
And that's especially true

for swing states with
races that are expected

to ultimately determine
the control of Congress,
as well as what the fucking country
looks like moving forward.
We're talking about states

that are some of the last
holdouts with abortion protection,
states that Trump and his allies fought
to try to overturn the election,

and where Republican
candidates are campaigning
on his lies about voter fraud.
And if those folks win their races,

even the ones that are
just about their state,

it could have serious
consequences nationwide

where they could get
off access to abortion,
not only for the residents of their state,
but further limit options

for those who live in neighboring
states with restrictions
and need to travel to get the procedure.
They could also,
and this is what we've been talking about
for the last two years,
seriously meddle with the election system,
or at the very least,

have people who are willing
to throw out the popular vote

and the will of the people
in a situation like 2020,

where Trump tried to get
officials in swing states
to do just that.

One of those key states,
of course, is Nevada.
Nevada specifically is one of the places

where Trump most intensely
contested the results.

And so it's not surprising
that it's one of the states

that has the higher relative
percentage of far right
and extremist candidates.

Some of those candidates
are running for key offices
that you might not think about,
like the office of the Attorney General,

who notably is one of
the main people fighting

against all the attempts to
destroy democracy in the state.

In that race, the current
Attorney General Aaron Ford
is facing right-wing lawyer Sigal Chattah,

who notably strongly beat
a more moderate Republican

in the primaries and has
many extremist views.
And that's just the public stuff.

That's not even including
her leaked text messages

where she said that the
AG should be lynched.
But to try to get a better lay of the land
and learn more about what is at stake
for the voters in Nevada and beyond,

we reached out to AG Ford
to talk about everything.
So AG Ford, I just have to jump into it.
There's a lot I wanna talk about,
but I guess my first question is just,

what do you think it says
about the state of politics

that Sigal Chattah is
the Republican nominee
for your job right now?
- Well, I think it says a couple things

because in addition to
her being the nominee,
we have seen a part of the party,
the reasonable part of the party

that has endorsed me
over their own candidate.
So it's clear that there's a schism
within the Republican party

and that schism has
produced on the one hand,
an extreme MAGA Republican, Sigal Chattah,

who does not have the best
interest of Nevadans in mind
and would be not a good fit
for the Attorney General's office.

And on the other side of
the schism are those who,
to be sure, maybe ideologically different
on approaches that we take as Democrats,
but are certainly more moderate
and more reasonable in their approach.
And those individuals, we've been able

to roll out a Republicans
for Ford Committee.
They have, to their credit,

supported the better
candidate in this race.

- So on the note of not having
the best interests in mind,
what do you mean there,

if we're comparing and
contrasting you and her?
- Well, there are a number of things
that I can offer in response.
I'll start with one
of the most prevalent headlines right now,
which is the Supreme Court
undermining a woman's right to choose
and getting rid of a constitutional right

for the first time in the
history of our country,
one that's been for 50 years,

and with Sigal having been
quoted or noted as having said
that she essentially wants to prosecute
and imprison women who seek abortions.

And that's not withstanding
the fact that in our state,

we have abortion rights
statutorily codified and protected.
So how she would go about doing that,
I'll leave it to her imagination.

But the point is she's adverse
to that particular right.
And frankly, from my perspective,
this job requires someone
who is going to respect the humanity

and dignity of everyone
who lives in this state.

And it's clear to me that she
does not respect the humanity

and dignity of people in
this state, including me.
She is quoted as having said she wants
to see me hanging from an effing crane.
And so those are two examples

of why I know she would
not have the best interest
of Nevadans at heart.
And we have to reject her.

- Also for anyone watching,
that is a legitimate quote.
That's from a leaked text message, right?

And she tried to defend
it by saying it was...

I don't understand how you
defend (chuckles) that statement.
- Yeah, well there's no defense to it.
She's not apologized.
Not that it would matter, frankly.
But you're right.

That's a leaked text
that she sent to someone
at some point last year, I believe it was.

And she did defend it by
saying she's Israeli American

and that's part of her
cultural dialogue, so to speak.
And she says that essentially,

she was essentially comparing
me to the leader of Hamas,
and that as terrorists talk,
that's how terrorists deal with traitors.
So again, her explanation is nonsensical

and certainly one that
doesn't speak to the fact
that here in this country,

when you talk about hanging
a Black man, that's lynching.
And at the end of the day,

there's no place for
that in Nevada politics,
in politics anywhere.

And I'm hoping, and I'm
grateful to see again,
some Republicans come out opposed to her
for that reason alone.

But certainly we have to,
as a state, reject that
and reelect me as Attorney General.

- So I believe you've used that
text message because it is,
it's disgusting.
Some would argue that it's disqualifying

as a reason that you
won't engage in a debate.
So I guess what do you say to push back

from people saying,
"Yes, it is disgusting,

but it shouldn't take
away a Nevadan's right

to see their AG talk
about the last four years

and what he would like
to do moving forward?"
- Well, there are a couple responses.

The first of which is that they
can absolutely hear me talk

about what I've done
in the last four years

and what I intend to
do the next four years,
because I am an open book in that regard.

I'm having interviews like
this, for example, with you,
which is open to the public.
I speak frequently and periodically
on what it is that we do in our office,
what we intend to continue doing.
And there will be no dearth of opportunity
for the public to hear about Aaron Ford
and what I stand for.
What I will also say is

that I do not feel
compelled for one second
to stand in the same room with a person

who wants to see me hanging
from a freaking crane.

And I say it freaking, but
that's not what she said.

And at the end of the day,
those words are hurtful words.

And it again demonstrates
she has no respect
for my humanity or my dignity.

And I will communicate with
the public in a different way.
- And then I think moving forward,

what would you be concerned
with if Republicans do win
in this upcoming election?

Where do you think that there
are the biggest concerns?

Obviously, you already
talked about abortion rights
and concerns there.
You're going against someone that has said

that they believe that
there was election fraud.

What do you think is
the worst case scenario

or what happens if you
don't get reelected?
- Well, we don't have to guess.
We don't have to surmise.
We can look at what's already happening.

Look, I don't know if people
call me progressive or not,
but here's what I know,

that the opposite of progressive
is regressive, (chuckles)

and I'd much rather be
progressive than regressive.

And I am absolutely
concerned about regressing

with a Republican in the
Attorney General's office.
We can see what happens.

We've regressed 50 years in
the context of abortion rights.

We've regressed to before
the times of civil rights
with attacks on voting rights.

We've regressed relative
to recognizing the humanity
of our LGBTQ+ brothers and sisters

by not being able to say
gay in Florida, for example.
And so these are examples of things
that Republicans are doing

and will continue to
do if we don't stand up

and push back and refuse
a regressive approach

to the way that we
coexist with one another.

- And could you also explain
what an Attorney General can do
to counter election deniers

and what you can do to
safeguard the institutions
that we're supposed to protect?
- Absolutely.

I don't have to guess or
surmise 'cause I've lived it.
Two years ago,
there was an attack on the basic integrity
of our election system.

Look, I took a oath of
office four years ago
that said I would protect

and defend the constitution
of the United States
and of the state of Nevada.
Didn't really realize that that meant

that I would literally be
defending the existence
of a democratic Republic,

with people trying to
undermine the actual existence
of our Republic by claiming
and lying about widespread voter fraud.
An Attorneys General can push back on that
by doing what I did.
And that's defeating lawsuits

that are waged to undermine
the electoral process.
There was at a minimum of six
that were directed toward the state
that my office had to defend,
and we prevailed on them.
To be sure,

when the off occurrences
of voter fraud do occur,

and every once in a while
they do, I prosecute them.
And proof positive of the fact
is that there was this one individual

who that has claimed to be
the poster child, essentially,

of the problems with widespread
voter fraud in Nevada,

who was over at news stations
like Fox, for example,
giving the story about his deceased wife,
God bless her soul,

whose ballot that was mailed
to her had been voted.

And he swore up and down he
didn't know what happened,

but he claimed that someone
voted his dead wife's ballot.
And that was the proof positive fact
that there was voter fraud going on
and shame on whoever voted her ballot.
Well, we investigated that

and found out that he voted
his dead wife's ballot,
and I prosecuted him.
I charged him for that
and took a guilty felony plea from him.

And so in the one-off
instances where they occur,
my office prosecutes those.
But what we do abide is people lying
about widespread voter fraud.
An Attorneys General can be those
who are protecting the frontline

as a frontline defense
and the last line defense,

protecting democratic
institutions and our processes.
- So AG Ford, I would say,
what is your message to voters
in regards to why it's important
to vote for Democrats this fall,
especially in a state like Nevada,

where it's a massively
important battleground state,
not only for the House of Representatives,

not only for the Senate, but
for your job specifically?

- Yeah, I mean, I think it's
an easy statement to make,
but it's a sale that we have to undertake.

We know what's gonna happen
if Republicans take over.
Look, in 2014...
Let me back up.

In 2012 I was first elected
to the Nevada state Senate,

elected into a majority
in the Senate Democrats
as the Senate Democrat.

And two years later,
we lost that majority.
We were in the minority.

I was elected minority
leader by my caucus.
What we saw them try to do,
relative to rolling back voting rights,

getting rid of early voting or
getting rid of Sunday voting,

which is a direct attack
on shows to the polls

and the Black voters and doing
other things of that sort.
We saw what happened.
Now we were able to push back
and we were able to stop some of that.

But we got there because
of not a red wave,
which is what they try to attribute it to
and what they say is happening,
potentially happened this year,

but because of what I
called a blue boycott.

It wasn't so much that
the Republicans swept.

It was that Democrats
boycotted and stayed home.
They didn't show up.
And because they didn't show up,
we almost lost so much in 2014.
We cannot have that repeat.

And that's not even a whole
decade away, in the past.

So my comments to Nevadans
is that it's important for us
to remember the difficulties
that we had to address and face in 2014
and what's ahead of us
and stand up and protect our rights
and continue putting people into office

who respect us from a humanity
and a dignity perspective,

but also from a constitutional
rights perspective.
- And AG Ford, are there any other issues
that you wanna highlight for voters
or anything else you wanna tell them?

Usually, I like to ask
the person I'm talking to,

what's a question that you
wish you had been set up for,
that you could speak on
that you think is important to voters?
- Well, I think we've covered quite a bit
of what I think is important.
And again, it's to focus on justice.
It's to focus on justice for all,

recognizing that it doesn't
always, for example,

manifest itself in the
criminal justice context,
in an arrest and a conviction.
Sometimes it manifests itself
in an exoneration and compensation.

And that too is justice because
systems are made of people.

The criminal justice
system is made of people,
and people are fallible.

And so justice requires us
to recognize that fallibility

and redress injustices
by pursuing justice.
And that's the criminal context,
but that's also in the civil context,

and it's also in the context
of our everyday interactions.

And it's important again, to
have people in this office,

the top law enforcement
officer position in this state
to understand the importance of justice

and to not shy away from pursuing
it under any circumstance.

And so I'm proud of the
work we've been able to do

in those areas that
I've talked about today.

And I think those efforts
speak for themselves.
And I would hope that that's a sufficient,

a reason for Nevadans to
continue to support me
and to return me to office in November.
- Ag Ford, thank you for the time.
- Happy to be here.
Thank you so much.

- So that was Nevada's
Attorney General, Aaron Ford.
And going into the midterms,

this is gonna be something
that I'm gonna be trying to do,

interviewing more
incumbents and candidates

as we get closer and
closer to the midterms,
because it's a lot of races that matter,

and some, not even at the top
of a lot of people's minds.

It's a number of these
potential nation changing races.

It's gonna be decided by
a fraction of a point.

But with all that I just
wanna say thank you once again
for watching and being subscribed
to my daily dives in the news.
This is the end of today's show,
and so I'll say my name's Philip DeFranco.
You've just been filled in.
I love yo faces and I'll see you tomorrow.
